column1: This list of Chinese monarchs includes rulers of China with various titles prior to the establishment of the Republic in 1912. From the Zhou dynasty until the Qin dynasty
column2: rulers usually held the title "king" (Chinese: 王; pinyin: wáng). With the separation of China into different Warring States
column3: this title had become so common that the unifier of China
column4: the first Qin Emperor Qin Shihuang created a new title for himself
column5: that of "emperor" (pinyin: huángdì). The title of Emperor of China continued to be used for the remainder of China's imperial history
column6: right down to the fall of the Qing dynasty in 1912.

column1: While many other monarchs existed in and around China throughout its history
column2: this list covers only those with a quasi-legitimate claim to the majority of China
column3: or those who have traditionally been named in king-lists. The following list of Chinese monarchs is in no way comprehensive.

column1: Chinese sovereigns were known by many different names
column2: and how they should be identified is often confusing. Sometimes the same emperor is commonly known by two or three separate names
column3: or the same name is used by emperors of different dynasties. The tables below do not necessarily include all of an emperor's names – for example
column4: posthumous names could run to more than twenty characters and were rarely used in historical writing – but
column6: the most commonly used name or naming convention has been indicated. Scholars also often use common terms to refer to some monarchs with special circumstances — "Modi" (末帝; "last emperor")
column12: etc.; these terms are not temple names

column2: the regnal or era name is changed in the same year as the death of the previous sovereign; in other cases
column3: the name change occurs in the subsequent year. Thus
column4: the date given for the beginning of a reign may actually refer to the first full year of the sovereign's reign.

column1: After King Nan was deposed by Qin
column2: Ji Jie (姬杰)
column3: Duke Wen of the vassal duchy of Eastern Zhou was proclaimed the new king of Zhou and claimed the title until his death in 249 BCE. However
column4: the King of Qin had taken possession of the Nine Tripod Cauldrons (九鼎)
column5: and Ji Jie's reign was not widely recognized.  Historians generally considered the title of Son of Heaven to be vacant from 256 to 221 BCE.

column1: Note: The State of Qin was founded in the 9th century BCE as a vassal of the Zhou dynasty.  In 325 BCE

column4: declared himself king and was given the regnal name King Huiwen of Qin (秦惠文王).  In 256 BCE

column7: Ying Zheng completed the conquest of the other states (kingdoms) and declared himself Qin Shi Huang
column8: or "First Emperor of Qin."  The unification of China under the Qin dynasty in 221 BCE is usually considered to be the beginning of Imperial China.

column1: Chinese convention: use "Han" + posthumous name (apart from Liu Bang
column2: who is known as "Han Gaozu")Note that the posthumous names of many Han monarchs bear the character "xiao" (孝; "filial")
column3: but this character is usually omitted by scholars when they are used (i.e. "Emperor Xiaowu" is normally known as "Emperor Wu")

column1: Chinese convention: Use "Jin" + posthumous name Note that the posthumous names of some Jin monarchs bore the character "xiao" (孝; "filial")
column2: but this character is usually omitted by scholars when referencing these monarchs by their posthumous names (i.e. "Emperor Xiaohui" is normally known as "Emperor Hui")

column1: Retreat of the Yuan court to the Mongolian Plateau after being overthrown by the Ming dynasty in China proper in 1368 (1368 – early 15th century)
Convention: use khan names or birth names.
The Shun dynasty was an imperial dynasty created in the brief lapse from Ming to Qing rule in China. It was a state set up by the peasants' rebellion
column2: in which they defeated the Ming forces
column3: but former Ming general Wu Sangui led the Qing forces into Beijing and the Qing forces defeated the rebels.

column1: The Southern Ming refers to the Ming loyalist regimes that existed in Southern China from 1644 to 1662.  The regime was established by the princes of the already destroyed Ming dynasty. All of these monarchs had their regimes crushed by the Qing forces very quickly. Koxinga (Zheng Chenggong) used the Ming dynasty's name and gathered forces before fleeing to Taiwan.

column2: both pronounced Lu; to distinguish them
column3: one is usually kept as Lu and the other spelled differently. Luh is from Cambridge History of China; Lou is from A.C. Moule's Rulers of China (1957). When one irregular spelling is used
column4: the other is kept as regular (Lu). The two systems are distinct and not used simultaneously.
